awd_titl_txt: Generation, functionalization, and distribution of de novo designed protein nanomaterials
awd_abstract_narration:
Proteins are large molecules that have complex three-dimensional (3D) structures that give them sophisticated cellular functions.  To provide access to complex protein structures not found in nature, Professors Baker and King of the University of Washington and Professor Yeates of University of California Los Angeles collaborate to compute and precisely control the assembly of proteins into 3D architectures.  The research team shares these capabilities with the engineering and scientific communities and constructs a Designed Protein Nanomaterial (DPN) database to enable others to rapidly build on these advances.  The long-term goal is to allow predictable design of protein-based materials for use in a wide range of applications such as targeted drug delivery, functional materials for energy conversion, and other chemical technologies.  The interdisciplinary project provides excellent research training opportunities to postdoctoral researchers and students.  

This research integrates theory, computation and experiment to close the design cycle on creation of new protein-based nanomaterials that are not currently accessible using conventional protein engineering approaches.  It develops strategies to prepare more robust and complex protein nanomaterials from modular building blocks, whose 3D assembly and disassembly can occur in response to changes in environmental conditions.  The research team recruits citizen scientists to solve complex protein design problems using Foldit, and to provide innovative input to enhance functionalization of such materials.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Through the funding of NSF in the last five years, we have been able to push the boundaries of de novo protein design to new heights. In particular, to create protein nanomaterials that are of use to the real world, we had to truly understand how to assemble these protein building blocks so we can produce tailor-made materials that are suited for specific applications, such has viral protein scaffolding for vaccine development or proteins that will disassemble in response to a low pH environment for targeted biologic payload delivery. Prior to the award, the state of the art of symmetrical protein design was limited to an extreme shotgun approach, where the whole of the Protein Data Bank (PDB) was scoured for building blocks which any of them may or may not have had unforeseen side effects and pitfalls. As the phrase goes, "beggars can't be choosers", we were not offered the luxury of using particular proteins.On the smaller scale of the particular aims of this award, we looked to understand and develop pipelines to design de novo proteins that could easily be adapted into building blocks for higher order assembly. First, we took on the endeavor to design ideal protein interactions from scratch. This resulted in a series of improvements to understanding the importance of hydrogen bonds in providing specificity to an protein-protein interaction (1, 2). This lead up to our capabilities to design highly specific hetero-oligomers (3, 4) in additon to biologically relevant environmentally responsive materials (5). Proteins also all have unique shapes, which are highly important when considering if they are able to simply "fit together" when designed. We have made strides in developing large libraries of shapes by carefully sculpting proteins into certain shapes that are more complementary than others (6). Taking advantage of the rest of the recently thriving protein design field, we also developed methods to take well characterized proteins that are not particularly suited for higher-order design and adapt them into useful building blocks (7, 8). Taken together on the building blocks front, we have been able to produce a suite of usable components that now rival—if not exceed—that we could scavenge from the PDB. Using these newly developed protein building blocks, we are now able to truly deviate from what we could accomplish prior. de novo designed proteins not only are more tolerant to mutations and behave better experimentally, they cover much more ground in structural space than that of native proteins, which are restricted by function in nature. From here, we have been able to design a new range of higher ordered symmetrical structures spanning from dihedral and point group symmetries (8-10), to 1D helical fibers (11), 2D arrays (3, 12, 13), and more recently 3D crystals (unpublished). Many of these symmetries were previously unsuccessful, largely due to the lack of good protein building blocks that were available and incomplete understanding of the underlying self-assembly requirements. Taking these achievements together, we are now able to pursue even more complex protein assemblies that were not available in the past. We currently are developing a suite of "functional" symmetrical nanomaterials, where the protein assembly itself has built-in traits rather than requiring another step in "activation" like adding dynamic functional features.  We have endowed one type of cage with sensitivity to specific proteases, thereby allowing destruction and release only in certain cellular environments. Also in the pipeline are nanocages in which innately are pH responsive. Another next-generation nanomaterial that has shown success are protein assemblies that "break" strict symmetry, utilizing pseudosymmetry like native viruses to assemble into large nanocages that are in the range of 100 nanometers in size; containing 900+ individual protein chains as opposed to 60 or 120 in the case of strict icosahedral symmetry. We believe these last five years have been highly fruitful in terms of accomplishments in pushing forward the boundaries of what is possible in symmetric de novo protein design. As described, we plan to continue our current trajectory and continue to improve upon our technologies so that designed proteins can tackle next-generation problems that the world faces today. 

References

1. 10.1126/science.aad8865

2. 10.7554/eLife.47839

3. 10.1021/jacs.9b01978

4. 10.1126/science.abj7662

5. 10.1126/science.aav7897

6. 10.1073/pnas.1908768117

7. 10.1038/nchem.2673

8. 10.1038/s41467-021-22276-z

9. 10.1126/science.abd9994

10. 10.1038/s41586-021-04184-w

11. 10.1126/science.aau3775

12. 10.1038/s41586-020-03120-8

13. 10.1038/s41586-019-1361-6




 


Last Modified: 02/14/2022
Modified by: David Baker
